narrative.title: 11-ex-2 — The Buried Rocking Horse
paragraphs: “Mpff!” cried a voice, and you discover your foot on a rocking horse’s face, half buried in trash. “Bless my buttons!” you exclaimed. “Sorry, old fellow.” “Don’t bother,” the horse replied with a sigh. “One rocker’s gone. That’s why my girl forgot me.” You wave the others over, hope rising if tools could set him right.

examples: I discovered a note under the door.

vocabulary.definition: moving back and forth; related to a rocking chair/horse.
covered by earth or other material.
examples: The coin was buried in sand.
The toy was buried under clothes.
“Wow!” she exclaimed when she saw the view.
He exclaimed at the good news.

vocabulary.definition: a person/creature in the same group; a companion.
examples: The stray dog found a fellow traveler.

vocabulary.definition: to take the trouble to do something; to annoy.
examples: Don’t bother with the broken lock.
Sorry to bother you so late.

vocabulary.definition: a long, soft breath showing sadness or relief.
examples: She let out a sigh of relief.

events.text: A muffled complaint came from underfoot.
They realized a toy’s face had been stepped on.
An apology drew the group to help.
The toy explained why its owner forgot it.
Aid was possible with the right tools, though fear lingered.

distractors: A child reclaimed the toy on the spot.
The ground opened into a cave.
